docs.text: An intelligent textbook for teaching reading skills to kindergarten students.

docs.title: About
docs.text: This intelligent textbook teaches reading skills to kindergarten students through interactive lessons, engaging simulations, and structured learning paths.

docs.title: About This Textbook
docs.text: Reading for Kindergarten is designed to help young learners develop foundational reading skills in an engaging and interactive way.

docs.title: Author
docs.text: Dan McCreary

docs.title: Contact
docs.text: For questions or feedback about this textbook, please visit the GitHub repository.

docs.title: Course Description
docs.text: This course introduces kindergarten students to foundational reading skills. It is designed to focus on creating phonemic awareness and letter sound correspondence.

docs.title: Target Audience
docs.text: Kindergarten students (ages 5-6)

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: None - this course is designed for beginning readers.

docs.title: List of Topics
docs.text:
• Sounds of English
  • Letters of English
  • One-to-one Correspondence
  • Sound-Letter Correspondence
  • Blending sounds into words

docs.title: Topics Excluded
docs.text:
• Parts of Speech
  • Sentences
  • Verb tenses
  • Reading beyond the word level
  • Irregular sight words
  • Spelling
  • Digraphs
  • Blends
  • Vowel Teams
  • Silent E

docs.title: Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

  1. Develop the concept of one-to-one correspondence
  2. Count the number of spoken words in a short sentence
  3. Recognize the first sound in a spoken word
  4. Recognize letters of the alphabet
  5. Understand basic phonics
  6. Associate consonant letters with their most common sound
  7. Associate five short vowel sounds and the six long vowel sounds with the five letters representing vowels
  8. Blend vowel-consonant words and consonant-vowel-consonant words using the vowel sound letter sounds taught in the prior step
  9. Recognize 18 sight words

docs.title: Bloom's Taxonomy Learning Objectives
docs.text: The learning outcomes above are categorized by Bloom's Taxonomy cognitive levels:

docs.title: Remember (Knowledge)
docs.text:
• Recognize all 26 letters of the alphabet (uppercase and lowercase)
  • Recall the most common sound for each consonant letter
  • Identify the five short vowel sounds and six long vowel sounds
  • Recognize 18 high-frequency sight words

docs.title: Understand (Comprehension)
docs.text:
• Demonstrate one-to-one correspondence between spoken and written words
  • Count the number of spoken words in a short sentence
  • Explain that letters represent sounds in spoken words
  • Understand that words are made up of individual sounds (phonemes)

docs.title: Apply (Application)
docs.text:
• Associate consonant letters with their most common sounds
  • Match vowel letters to their short and long sounds
  • Blend vowel-consonant (VC) words using learned letter sounds
  • Blend consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) words using learned letter sounds

docs.title: Analyze (Analysis)
docs.text:
• Identify the first sound in a spoken word
  • Segment words into individual sounds
  • Distinguish between different vowel sounds in words

docs.title: Create
docs.text:
• Create their own small words including nonsense words
  • Use gestures and arm motions to associate motion with the shape of a letter

docs.title: Evaluation
docs.text:
• Accuracy of sound letter correspondence to sounds taught
  • Accuracy when blending sounds into words
  • Mastery of specific learning objectives

Note: we do not do percentage of scores at this young age level

docs.title: Chapters Overview
docs.text: Welcome to Reading for Kindergarten! This textbook is organized into 11 chapters that guide young learners through the fundamentals of reading.

docs.title: Chapter Structure
docs.text:
Each chapter builds on previous knowledge, following a carefully designed learning progression from foundational concepts to independent reading skills.

docs.title: How to Use This Book
docs.text:
1. Start at Chapter 1 - Build foundational skills before moving forward

  3. Take the chapter quizzes - Check understanding before moving on
  4. Celebrate progress - Reading is a journey worth celebrating!

docs.title: Total Concepts: 195
docs.text: This textbook covers 195 carefully sequenced concepts that build the foundation for reading success.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This foundational chapter introduces children to the world of reading by building essential pre-reading skills. Children will develop an understanding of spoken language, learn to listen carefully, and discover that printed words carry meaning.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Identify that spoken words are made up of sounds
  • Understand: Explain that print carries meaning
  • Apply: Demonstrate proper book handling (left to right, top to bottom)

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Getting ready to read starts with understanding that the words we speak can be written down and read. This chapter helps young learners make the connection between spoken and written language while building the listening and attention skills needed for reading success.

docs.title: Concepts Covered (15)
docs.text: Concept Description Spoken Language Understanding that we communicate through words Listening Paying attention to sounds and words Sounds Recognizing that language is made of sounds Speech Understanding how we make sounds with our mouths Words Learning that speech is organized into words Print Awareness Knowing that print carries meaning Book Concepts Understanding how books work Page Learning about pages in a book Left-to-Right Reading direction in English Top-to-Bottom Reading from top to bottom of page Letter Concept Understanding that words are made of letters Alphabet The set of all letters Letter Names Each letter has a name Letter Order Letters go in ABC order Letter Shapes Each letter has a unique shape

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Print: Written or typed words
  • Letter: A symbol that represents a sound
  • Alphabet: All the letters in order (A-Z)
  • Word: A group of letters that means something

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Story Time: Listen to a story and point to words as they are read
  2. Book Walk: Explore a book's cover, pages, and pictures
  3. Letter Hunt: Find letters in the classroom environment
  4. ABC Song: Sing the alphabet song together

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: None - this is the starting chapter!

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 2: Learning Uppercase Letters

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This chapter introduces all 26 uppercase letters of the English alphabet. Children will learn to recognize, name, and identify each capital letter through engaging activities and practice.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Name all 26 uppercase letters
  • Understand: Recognize uppercase letters in different fonts and contexts
  • Apply: Identify uppercase letters in words and environmental print

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Uppercase letters (also called capital letters or "big letters") are often the first letters children learn. They appear at the beginning of sentences and names, and their distinct shapes make them easier for young learners to distinguish. This chapter provides systematic instruction in all 26 uppercase letters.

docs.title: Concepts Covered (26)
docs.text: Letter Example Word A Apple B Ball C Cat D Dog E Elephant F Fish G Goat H Hat I Ice cream J Jam K Kite L Lion M Moon N Nest O Orange P Pig Q Queen R Rainbow S Sun T Tree U Umbrella V Vase W Wagon X X-ray Y Yo-yo Z Zebra

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Uppercase: Capital letters (A, B, C...)
  • Letter name: What we call each letter
  • Capital letter: Another name for uppercase

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Letter of the Day: Focus on one letter with songs, crafts, and games
  2. Letter Sorting: Sort magnetic letters by shape features
  3. Name Writing: Practice writing first name in uppercase
  4. Letter Matching: Match uppercase letters to pictures

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Chapter 1: Getting Ready to Read

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 3: Learning Lowercase Letters

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This chapter introduces all 26 lowercase letters and helps children understand the relationship between uppercase and lowercase letter pairs. Lowercase letters appear most frequently in text, making their recognition essential for reading.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Name all 26 lowercase letters
  • Understand: Match lowercase letters to their uppercase partners
  • Apply: Identify lowercase letters in words and sentences

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Most of the letters children encounter in books are lowercase (or "little letters"). This chapter builds on uppercase letter knowledge to introduce lowercase forms, helping children recognize both versions of each letter and understand that they represent the same sound.

docs.title: Concepts Covered (26)
docs.text: Lowercase Uppercase Partner Example Word a A ant b B bed c C cup d D doll e E egg f F fan g G gift h H house i I igloo j J jar k K key l L lamp m M map n N nut o O octopus p P pen q Q quilt r R ring s S sock t T top u U up v V van w W web x X box y Y yarn z Z zip

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Lowercase: Small letters (a, b, c...)
  • Letter pair: Uppercase and lowercase of the same letter (A/a)
  • Match: Finding letters that go together

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Letter Pair Match: Connect uppercase and lowercase letters
  2. Mixed Letter Sort: Sort a pile of letters into uppercase and lowercase groups
  3. Find the Lowercase: Circle lowercase letters in simple words
  4. Letter Formation: Practice writing lowercase letters

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Chapter 2: Learning Uppercase Letters

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 4: Hearing Sounds in Words

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This chapter develops phonemic awarenessthe ability to hear, identify, and manipulate individual sounds in spoken words. These listening skills are foundational for connecting letters to sounds and learning to read.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Identify rhyming words
  • Understand: Recognize that words are made up of individual sounds (phonemes)
  • Apply: Identify beginning, middle, and ending sounds in words
  • Analyze: Break words into syllables and individual sounds

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Before children can connect letters to sounds, they need to hear and distinguish the sounds in words. This chapter focuses on listening activities that build phonemic awarenesshearing initial sounds, final sounds, rhymes, and syllables without focusing on letters.

docs.title: Concepts Covered (13)
docs.text: Concept Description Phoneme The smallest unit of sound in a word Phonemic Awareness Ability to hear and work with sounds Initial Sound The first sound in a word Final Sound The last sound in a word Medial Sound The middle sound in a word Rhyme Words that end with the same sound Rhyming Words Words like cat, hat, bat Syllable Word parts with one vowel sound Onset The beginning consonant(s) of a syllable Rime The vowel and what follows in a syllable Sound Isolation Identifying one sound in a word Sound Segmentation Breaking a word into its sounds Sound Counting Counting sounds in a word

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Rhyme: Words that sound the same at the end (cat/hat)
  • Sound: What we hear when we say a letter
  • Beginning sound: The first sound in a word
  • Ending sound: The last sound in a word

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Rhyme Time: Identify words that rhyme (Do cat and hat rhyme?)
  2. Sound Safari: Find objects that start with the same sound
  3. Clap the Syllables: Clap once for each syllable in a word
  4. What's the Sound?: Identify beginning/ending sounds in words
  5. Sound Stretching: Stretch words out to hear each sound (c-a-t)

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Chapter 1: Getting Ready to Read

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 5: Consonant Sounds

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This chapter introduces the sounds that consonant letters make. Children will learn to associate each consonant letter with its most common sound, building the foundation for decoding words.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Produce the sound for each consonant letter
  • Understand: Explain that consonants are letters that are not vowels
  • Apply: Identify consonant sounds at the beginning of words

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Consonants are the 21 letters that are not vowels (A, E, I, O, U). Each consonant makes a specific sound, and learning these sounds is essential for sounding out words. This chapter focuses on the most common sound each consonant makes.

docs.title: Concepts Covered (23)
docs.text: Consonant Sound Example Consonant (concept) Understanding consonants - Consonant Sounds All consonant sounds - B sound /b/ ball C sound /k/ cat D sound /d/ dog F sound /f/ fish G sound /g/ goat H sound /h/ hat J sound /j/ jam K sound /k/ kite L sound /l/ lamp M sound /m/ moon N sound /n/ nest P sound /p/ pig Q sound /kw/ queen R sound /r/ ring S sound /s/ sun T sound /t/ top V sound /v/ van W sound /w/ wagon X sound /ks/ box Y sound /y/ yes Z sound /z/ zebra

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Consonant: A letter that is not a vowel
  • Sound: What a letter says
  • Beginning sound: The consonant sound at the start of a word

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Sound Cards: Match consonant letters to pictures starting with that sound
  2. Sound Sorting: Sort pictures by beginning consonant sound
  3. Letter Sound Song: Sing songs that emphasize each consonant sound
  4. Touch and Say: Touch a letter, say its sound

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Chapter 2: Learning Uppercase Letters
  • Chapter 3: Learning Lowercase Letters
  • Chapter 4: Hearing Sounds in Words

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 6: Vowel Sounds

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This chapter introduces the vowels (A, E, I, O, U) and their sounds. Children will learn that each vowel makes both a short sound and a long sound, with a focus on short vowel sounds for beginning readers.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Name the five vowels
  • Understand: Explain the difference between short and long vowel sounds
  • Apply: Produce short vowel sounds in CVC words

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Vowels are special letters because every word needs at least one! The five vowels (A, E, I, O, U) each make two main sounds: a short sound and a long sound. Beginning readers start with short vowel sounds, which appear in simple words like "cat," "bed," and "pig."

docs.title: Concepts Covered (14)
docs.text: Concept Sound Example Vowel (concept) Understanding vowels - Vowels A, E, I, O, U - Short Vowel Sounds Quick vowel sounds - Long Vowel Sounds Vowel says its name - Short A // cat Short E // bed Short I /-/ pig Short O /O/ hot Short U /m/ cup Long A // cake Long E // feet Long I /+/ bike Long O /M/ home Long U /k/ cube

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Vowel: The letters A, E, I, O, U
  • Short vowel: The quick sound a vowel makes
  • Long vowel: When a vowel says its name

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Vowel Song: Learn a song about the five vowels
  2. Short Vowel Pictures: Sort pictures by short vowel sound
  3. Vowel Hand Motions: Use hand signals for each vowel sound
  4. Middle Sound: Identify the vowel sound in the middle of CVC words

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Chapter 5: Consonant Sounds

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 7: Connecting Letters and Sounds

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This chapter strengthens the connection between letters and their sounds through multisensory activities. Children will practice letter formation while saying sounds, building strong letter-sound associations.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Automatically recall sounds when seeing letters
  • Understand: Explain how letters represent sounds
  • Apply: Write letters while saying their sounds

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Strong readers instantly connect letters to sounds without thinking. This chapter uses kinesthetic (movement-based) and multisensory techniques to cement letter-sound relationships. By tracing, writing, and physically forming letters while saying sounds, children build automatic recognition.

docs.title: Concepts Covered (8)
docs.text: Concept Description Letter-Sound Correspondence Connecting letters to their sounds Letter-Sound Association Automatic recall of sounds for letters Letter Formation How to write each letter Kinesthetic Learning Learning through movement Tracing Letters Following letter shapes Sky Writing Writing letters in the air Sand/Salt Tracing Tracing letters in textured materials Multisensory Approach Using multiple senses to learn

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Letter-sound: Connecting what a letter looks like to what it sounds like
  • Formation: How to write a letter
  • Trace: Follow the shape of a letter

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Sky Writing: Write letters large in the air while saying sounds
  2. Sand Tray: Trace letters in sand or salt while saying sounds
  3. Letter Formation Practice: Use proper strokes to write letters
  4. Touch and Say: Touch textured letters while saying sounds
  5. Rainbow Writing: Write letters in multiple colors while repeating sounds

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Chapter 5: Consonant Sounds
  • Chapter 6: Vowel Sounds

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 8: Blending Sounds into Words

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This chapter teaches children to blend individual sounds together to read words. Starting with simple two-sound words and progressing to three-sound (CVC) words, children will develop essential decoding skills.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Recognize common word patterns (VC, CVC)
  • Understand: Explain how sounds blend together to make words
  • Apply: Blend sounds to read simple words
  • Analyze: Decode unfamiliar CVC words

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Blending is the key skill that turns letter sounds into real words. This chapter teaches children to smoothly connect sounds together, starting with two sounds (VC words like "at") and building to three sounds (CVC words like "cat"). This is where reading begins!

docs.title: Concepts Covered (15)
docs.text: Concept Description Blending Putting sounds together to make words Sound Blending Connecting sounds smoothly VC Pattern Vowel-consonant words (at, in, up) CVC Pattern Consonant-vowel-consonant words (cat, dog) Word Patterns Common letter arrangements Decoding Using letter sounds to read words Sounding Out Saying each sound then blending Word Reading Reading whole words Word Families Words with same ending (-at, -an, -ig) Onset-Rime Blending Combining beginning sound with word ending Continuous Blending Holding sounds together smoothly Word Building Making words from letters Letter Manipulation Changing letters to make new words Simple Words Easy decodable words Decodable Text Text with words students can sound out

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Blend: Put sounds together to say a word
  • Sound out: Say each sound in a word
  • CVC word: A word with consonant-vowel-consonant (cat, dog, pig)
  • Word family: Words that end the same way (-at: cat, hat, bat)

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Sound Slides: Slide finger under letters while blending sounds
  2. Word Family Sorting: Group words by their ending pattern
  3. Build-a-Word: Use letter tiles to build CVC words
  4. Blending Practice: Blend teacher-provided sounds into words
  5. Decodable Book Reading: Read simple books with CVC words

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Chapter 7: Connecting Letters and Sounds

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 9: Learning Sight Words

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This chapter introduces high-frequency sight wordscommon words that children should recognize instantly without sounding out. These words appear frequently in text and include many words that don't follow regular phonics patterns.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Instantly recognize common sight words
  • Understand: Explain why some words need to be memorized
  • Apply: Read sentences containing sight words fluently

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Sight words (also called high-frequency words) are words that appear so often in text that children need to recognize them instantly. Some sight words follow phonics rules (like "and" and "it"), while others don't (like "the" and "said"). Learning these words by heart helps children read more fluently.

docs.title: Concepts Covered (20)
docs.text: Concept Example Words Sight Words (concept) Understanding sight words High-Frequency Words Words that appear often the Most common English word a Article is Being verb to Direction word and Connecting word I Self-reference can Ability word see Vision verb we Group pronoun like Preference word my Possession word he Male pronoun she Female pronoun you Address pronoun it Object pronoun go Movement verb me Object pronoun do Action verb

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Sight word: A word you know by looking at it
  • High-frequency: Appears very often
  • Memorize: Learn by heart
  • Instantly: Right away, without sounding out

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Sight Word Flashcards: Practice instant recognition
  2. Sight Word Bingo: Play bingo with sight words
  3. Sentence Building: Make sentences using sight words
  4. Word Wall: Add new sight words to classroom display
  5. Sight Word Hunt: Find sight words in books and around the room

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Chapter 8: Blending Sounds into Words

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 10: Practice, Assessment, and Learning Strategies

docs.title: Chapter 10: Practice, Assessment, and Learning Strategies
Overview
docs.text: This chapter focuses on building reading fluency through systematic practice and introduces strategies for monitoring progress. Children will develop habits for successful reading practice and learn to self-assess their learning.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Recall effective practice strategies
  • Understand: Explain why practice leads to mastery
  • Apply: Use practice routines independently
  • Evaluate: Self-assess reading progress

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: Becoming a good reader requires lots of practice! This chapter helps children understand that reading improves with repetition and teaches them how to practice effectively. It also introduces ways to track progress and celebrate achievements.

docs.title: Concepts Covered (15)
docs.text: Concept Description Repetition Practicing again and again Practice Regular work to improve skills Mastery Knowing something really well Fluency Reading smoothly and quickly Accuracy Reading words correctly Automaticity Reading without having to think hard Assessment Checking what you've learned Progress Monitoring Tracking improvement over time Self-Assessment Checking your own learning Reading Rate How fast you read Expression Reading with feeling Confidence Feeling sure about reading Independence Reading on your own Goal Setting Deciding what to work toward Celebration Recognizing achievements

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Practice: Doing something again and again to get better
  • Fluent: Reading smoothly without stopping
  • Progress: Getting better over time
  • Goal: Something you're working toward

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Daily Reading Practice: Establish consistent reading routines
  2. Timed Reading: Read familiar passages to build fluency
  3. Reading Journal: Track books read and progress
  4. Partner Reading: Practice reading with a classmate
  5. Self-Check: Use checklists to monitor own learning

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Chapter 8: Blending Sounds into Words
  • Chapter 9: Learning Sight Words

docs.title: Next Chapter
docs.text: Chapter 11: Building Reading Skills

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This capstone chapter brings together all previously learned skills to develop independent reading abilities. Children will apply their knowledge of letters, sounds, and words to read simple texts on their own.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

  • Remember: Apply letter-sound knowledge automatically
  • Understand: Comprehend simple texts
  • Apply: Read emergent reader books independently
  • Create: Build and write simple words and sentences

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text: This final chapter celebrates how far young readers have come! Children will apply all their skillsletter recognition, phonemic awareness, phonics, sight words, and fluencyto read simple books independently. This is where all the pieces come together for the joy of reading!

docs.title: Application Skills (10)
docs.text: Concept Description Word Creation Building words from sounds Word Manipulation Changing words by changing letters Word Recognition Knowing words when you see them Spelling Patterns Common letter arrangements Reading Strategies Ways to figure out words Context Clues Using pictures and story to help Self-Correction Fixing mistakes while reading Rereading Reading again for understanding Picture Support Using pictures to help read Predicting Guessing what comes next

docs.title: Capstone Skills (10)
docs.text: Concept Description Independent Reading Reading on your own Emergent Reader A beginning reader Emergent Text Simple books for beginners Reading Comprehension Understanding what you read Retelling Telling the story in your own words Story Elements Characters, setting, events Reading for Meaning Understanding the message Reading Enjoyment Finding pleasure in reading Book Selection Choosing appropriate books Reading Identity Seeing yourself as a reader

docs.title: Key Vocabulary
docs.text:
• Independent: Doing it by yourself
  • Comprehension: Understanding what you read
  • Emergent reader: Someone just learning to read
  • Retell: Tell the story again in your own words

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Independent Reading Time: Read self-selected books quietly
  2. Story Retelling: Share what happened in a book
  3. Word Building Games: Create words using letter tiles
  4. Reading Celebration: Share favorite books with the class
  5. Reading Goals: Set personal reading goals

docs.title: Prerequisites

docs.title: Congratulations!
docs.text: You have completed Reading for Kindergarten! You are now an emergent reader ready for new reading adventures!

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
• Continue reading every day
  • Try books with more words
  • Read to family and friends
  • Visit the library for new books
  • Keep practicing and growing as a reader!

docs.title: What is a Learning Graph?
docs.text:
A learning graph is a structured representation of how concepts in a course relate to each other. It shows:

  • Concept Dependencies: Which concepts must be learned before others
  • Learning Pathways: Multiple routes through the material
  • Concept Categories: How concepts are organized by type

docs.title: Learning Graph Overview
docs.text:

  • 195 concepts covering foundational reading skills
  • 11 taxonomy categories organizing concepts by type
  • 265 dependencies showing prerequisite relationships

docs.title: Course Description Assessment Report
docs.text: Course: Reading for Kindergarten Assessment Date: December 4, 2025 Analyzer Version: 0.03

docs.title: Quality Rating: Good - Minor improvements recommended
docs.text: The course description now includes most required elements with good coverage of Bloom's Taxonomy levels. A few enhancements would bring it to excellent status.

docs.title: Detailed Scoring Breakdown
docs.text:
Element Points Earned Max Points Notes Title 4 5 Title in metadata; main header could include course name Target Audience 5 5 Clearly specified: Kindergarten students (ages 5-6) Prerequisites 5 5 Explicitly stated: None Main Topics Covered 8 10 5 topics listed; could benefit from 2-3 more subtopics Topics Excluded 5 5 Excellent - 10 clear exclusions defined Learning Outcomes Header 5 5 Clear statement present Remember Level 10 10 4 specific, actionable outcomes Understand Level 10 10 4 specific, actionable outcomes Apply Level 10 10 4 specific, actionable outcomes Analyze Level 8 10 3 outcomes present; meets minimum Evaluate Level 4 10 Present but in separate section; needs Bloom's verbs Create Level 3 10 Only 1 outcome; needs 2+ more Descriptive Context 5 5 Good context about phonemic awareness focus

Total: 82/100

docs.title: Areas Needing Improvement
docs.text:
1. Evaluate Level (4/10)
  2. The "Evaluation" section exists but uses assessment criteria format rather than student learning outcomes
  3. Current: "Accuracy of sound letter correspondence" - this describes how to assess, not what students will do
  4. Impact: Missing evaluation-level cognitive skills in learning graph

  5. Recommendation: Reframe as student actions using Bloom's verbs (judge, assess, determine, compare)

  6. Create Level (3/10)

  7. Only 1 outcome: "Create their own small words including nonsense words"
  8. Impact: Limited capstone concepts for learning graph

  9. Recommendation: Add 2-3 more creative outcomes

  10. Main Topics (8/10)

  11. 5 topics is adequate but could be expanded
  12. Consider adding: Phonemic Awareness, Sight Words, Word Building

  13. Impact: More topics = more concept clusters in learning graph

  14. Analyze Level (8/10)

  15. 3 outcomes meets minimum requirement
  16. Could add 1-2 more for stronger coverage

docs.title: Priority 1: Restructure Evaluate Level
docs.text:
Replace the current "## Evaluation" section with Bloom's Taxonomy formatted outcomes:

### Evaluate (Evaluation)
- Determine whether a spoken word begins with a target sound
- Judge if a letter-sound match is correct or incorrect
- Assess whether a blended word sounds like a real word
- Compare two words to identify if they share the same initial sound

docs.title: Priority 2: Expand Create Level
docs.text:
Add 2-3 more outcomes:

### Create
- Create their own small words including nonsense words
- Compose new CVC words by selecting consonants and vowels
- Build word families by changing the initial consonant (cat → bat → hat)
- Invent rhyming word pairs using learned sounds

docs.title: Priority 3: Add to Analyze Level (Optional)
docs.text:
### Analyze (Analysis)
- Identify the first sound in a spoken word
- Segment words into individual sounds
- Distinguish between different vowel sounds in words
- Break apart CVC words into onset and rime

docs.title: Priority 4: Expand Topics List (Optional)
docs.text:
## List of Topics

- Sounds of English
- Letters of English
- One-to-one Correspondence
- Sound-Letter Correspondence
- Blending sounds into words
- Phonemic Awareness
- Short and Long Vowel Sounds
- High-Frequency Sight Words

docs.text:
Based on current content:

Topic Area Estimated Concepts Letters (uppercase/lowercase) 52 Consonant Sounds 21 Vowel Sounds (short + long) 11 Sight Words 18 Phonemic Awareness Skills 15-20 Blending Skills 10-15 One-to-One Correspondence 5-8 Subtotal ~130-145

docs.title: Target: 200 concepts
docs.text:
To reach 200 concepts: - The current description can support ~130-150 concepts - Adding expanded Evaluate and Create outcomes would add ~20-30 more - Expanding the topics list would add another ~20-30

Assessment: With minor improvements, this course description can support 200 concepts.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Since the score is 82/100 (close to 85 threshold):

  1. Recommended: Address Priority 1 (Evaluate level) and Priority 2 (Create level)
  2. After updates: Re-run assessment to confirm score ≥ 85
  3. Then: Proceed to learning graph generation

Alternatively: The current description is adequate for learning graph generation if you want to proceed now, though the graph may have fewer evaluation and creation-level concepts.

docs.title: What are MicroSims?
docs.text: MicroSims are small, focused interactive simulations that help students learn through hands-on exploration.

docs.title: Available MicroSims
docs.text: MicroSims will be added here as they are developed.

docs.title: List of Possible MicroSims
docs.text:
Letter Recognition

  1. Alphabet Explorer - Interactive display of all 26 letters; click to hear the letter name and see uppercase/lowercase forms
  2. Letter Matching Game - Match uppercase letters to their lowercase partners
  3. Letter Hunt - Find and click specific letters hidden among other letters
  4. Letter Tracing - Trace letters with finger/mouse to learn letter shapes

Phonemic Awareness

  1. First Sound Finder - Listen to a word, identify the first sound from choices
  2. Sound Counter - Count phonemes in spoken words by tapping/clicking
  3. Word Counter - Count spoken words in a sentence (one-to-one correspondence)
  4. Rhyme Time - Match words that rhyme together

Letter-Sound Correspondence

  1. Consonant Sound Match - Click a consonant letter, hear its most common sound
  2. Vowel Sound Explorer - Interactive vowel chart showing short and long sounds
  3. Sound-to-Letter Match - Hear a sound, click the letter that makes it
  4. Letter Sound Keyboard - Virtual keyboard that plays sounds when letters are pressed

Blending

  1. CVC Word Builder - Drag letters to build consonant-vowel-consonant words
  2. VC Word Blender - Blend vowel-consonant combinations (at, in, up)
  3. Sound Slider - Slide through sounds to blend them into words
  4. Word Machine - Input sounds, watch them combine into a word

Sight Words

  1. Sight Word Flashcards - Interactive flashcards for 18 sight words
  2. Sight Word Memory - Match pairs of sight word cards
  3. Sight Word Bingo - Listen and find sight words on a bingo card

Multi-Skill Games

  1. Letter Motion Maker - Associate arm gestures/motions with letter shapes (supports "Create" objective)
  2. Nonsense Word Generator - Build and sound out made-up CVC words
  3. Reading Progress Path - Visual journey through all skills with mini-challenges

docs.title: Letter Matching Game
docs.text: Run the Letter Matching Game Fullscreen

docs.title: About This MicroSim
docs.text: This interactive game helps kindergarten students learn to recognize and match uppercase letters with their lowercase partners. Students click on an uppercase letter card, then click on its matching lowercase letter to form a pair.

docs.title: How to Play
docs.text:
1. Click on any letter card to select it (it will turn gold)
  2. Click on the matching letter in the other row (uppercase to lowercase or vice versa)
  3. Matched pairs turn green and show a connecting line
  4. Complete all matches to see the celebration!

docs.title: Controls
docs.text:
• New Game Button: Start a fresh game with shuffled letters
  • Pairs Slider: Adjust difficulty by changing the number of letter pairs (4-8)

docs.text:

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text: This MicroSim supports the following learning objectives from the course:

docs.title: Remember (Knowledge)
docs.text: • Recognize all 26 letters of the alphabet (uppercase and lowercase)

docs.title: Understand (Comprehension)
docs.text: • Demonstrate understanding that uppercase and lowercase letters represent the same sound

docs.title: Apply (Application)
docs.text: • Associate uppercase letters with their lowercase counterparts

docs.title: Introduction (2 minutes)
docs.text:
• Explain that letters come in two forms: "big letters" (uppercase) and "small letters" (lowercase)
  • Show examples of a few letter pairs (A/a, B/b, C/c)

docs.title: Guided Practice (5 minutes)
docs.text:
• Demonstrate how to play the game with students watching
  • Click an uppercase letter and ask students which lowercase letter matches
  • Complete 2-3 matches together

docs.title: Independent Practice (10 minutes)
docs.text:
• Let students play individually or in pairs
  • Start with 4 pairs for beginners, increase to 6-8 as skills improve
  • Encourage students to say the letter name when they click it

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
• Observe which letters students match quickly vs. struggle with
  • Note accuracy (score vs. attempts ratio)
  • Identify specific letter pairs that need more practice

docs.title: Extensions
docs.text:
• Challenge: Complete the game with the fewest attempts
  • Verbal Practice: Say the letter name and sound when matching
  • Writing Connection: After matching, practice writing the letter pair

docs.title: Educational Notes
docs.text:
This game reinforces letter recognition through:

  • Visual Discrimination: Students must distinguish between uppercase and lowercase letter forms
  • Color Coding: Uppercase letters appear in blue, lowercase in coral, helping students categorize
  • Immediate Feedback: Green highlighting confirms correct matches
  • Progressive Difficulty: The slider allows scaffolding from 4 to 8 pairs
  • Celebration: Positive reinforcement when all matches are complete

docs.title: Tips for Teachers
docs.text:
1. Start Simple: Begin with 4 pairs until students understand the game
  2. Focus on Tricky Letters: Some pairs are harder (b/d, p/q, g/q) - use the game to identify which need extra practice
  3. Pair Work: Have students work in pairs, taking turns choosing letters
  4. Verbalization: Encourage saying letter names aloud to reinforce audio-visual connection

docs.title: Talking Letters
docs.text: Run the Talking Letters MicroSim Fullscreen

docs.title: About This MicroSim
docs.text: This interactive alphabet display helps kindergarten students learn letter names by clicking on any letter to hear it spoken aloud. The MicroSim uses the Web Speech API built into modern browsers, requiring no external audio files.

docs.title: How to Use
docs.text:
1. Click any letter to hear it spoken aloud
  2. Watch the display - the letter appears large in the corner with animated sound waves
  3. Toggle case - use the checkbox to switch between uppercase and lowercase letters

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• All 26 letters displayed in a responsive grid
  • Text-to-speech using the browser's built-in Web Speech API
  • Visual feedback - letters highlight when hovered and turn green when speaking
  • Large letter display shows the current letter being spoken
  • Animated sound waves indicate audio is playing
  • Case toggle to practice both uppercase and lowercase letters

docs.title: Embedding This MicroSim
docs.text:
You can include this MicroSim on your website using the following iframe:

<iframe src="https://dmccreary.github.io/reading-for-kindergarten/sims/talking-letters/main.html" height="452px" scrolling="no"></iframe>

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text: This MicroSim supports the following learning objectives from the course:

docs.title: Remember (Knowledge)
docs.text:
• Recognize all 26 letters of the alphabet (uppercase and lowercase)
  • Recall the name of each letter

docs.title: Understand (Comprehension)
docs.text:
• Associate the visual shape of each letter with its spoken name
  • Understand the difference between uppercase and lowercase letter forms

docs.title: Introduction (2 minutes)
docs.text:
• Explain that each letter has a name
  • Demonstrate clicking on a few letters (A, B, C) and listening to the names

docs.title: Guided Practice (5 minutes)
docs.text:
• Click through the alphabet together as a class
  • Ask students to predict the next letter name before clicking
  • Toggle to lowercase and repeat with a few letters

docs.title: Independent Practice (10 minutes)
docs.text:
• Let students explore freely, clicking letters of interest
  • Challenge: "Can you find the letter that starts your name?"
  • Challenge: "Click all the vowels: A, E, I, O, U"

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text:
• Point to random letters and ask students to name them before clicking
  • Observe which letters students click repeatedly (may indicate uncertainty)

docs.title: Extensions
docs.text:
• Letter Hunt: Call out a letter name, students race to click it
  • Alphabetical Order: Click letters in order A-Z
  • Name Spelling: Click letters to spell students' names
  • Vowel vs Consonant: Identify and click only vowels or only consonants

docs.title: Browser Compatibility
docs.text: The Web Speech API is supported in all modern browsers: - Chrome (recommended) - Firefox - Safari - Edge

docs.title: Voice Selection
docs.text: The MicroSim uses the browser's default voice. Voice quality and accent may vary by: - Operating system (Windows, macOS, iOS, Android) - Browser - System language settings

docs.title: Audio Settings
docs.text: The speech is configured for young learners: - Rate: 0.8 (slightly slower than normal) - Pitch: 1.1 (slightly higher for clarity) - Volume: 1.0 (full volume)

docs.title: Tips for Teachers
docs.text:
1. Volume Check: Ensure classroom speakers or headphones are working before the lesson
  2. First Click: Some browsers require a user interaction before audio plays - have students click any letter to start
  3. Repetition: Encourage students to click letters multiple times to reinforce learning
  4. Lowercase Practice: Use the toggle to practice lowercase recognition after uppercase is mastered
  5. Pair Work: Have students take turns - one clicks, one predicts the letter name
